review_title: Tutoring is nice for a student searching for par time jobs
job_title: Peer Tutor in San Antonio, TX
pros: The environment is fantastic Good education Feel valued
cons: Not so much growth opportunity

job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: There was a lot of flexibility
cons: There wasn't a lot of hours

job_title: Department Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
* Easy access for students
* Working alongside professors
* Typically allowed to study/work on homework during downtime
cons:
* Pay is typically minimum wage when going through Work-Study

I recommend students try to apply to work at a nearby place or at the on-campus businesses rather than relying on work-study. Sometimes the University offers jobs to students outside of work-study for a higher wage.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Worked with a specific department
-Time to study and read/work on assignments
-Staff was kind and easygoing
cons:
-Often had to go back and forth on campus just to be able to access the office (It was always locked)
-Communication through emails takes way too long, often left with no response until a few days later
-Wage-wise, they underpay their employees

job_title: Admission Counselor in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Good insurance benefits
Tuition employee benefit 
Paid holidays
cons:
Poor leadership 
High turn-over 
Political work environment

job_title: Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Small community that is easy to network with
cons: Overworked and underpaid with no appreciation

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Very collegial environment. Everyone is friendly and supportive. Students are studying hard which makes you want to provide more to them.
cons: Nothing to complain about. Wonderful place to work at if you do not care about research much. If you me care about research, just go for a research school.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Working at St. Mary's is like working with family. People care about you. And you have fun!
cons: Politics with upper management. But to be expected. A higher base salary would be nice.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: great values, great people, and great school
cons: no cons to date that I can think of

review_title: A nice but cheap place to work
job_title: Web Developer in San Antonio, TX
pros: Lots of flexibility, a positive team, lots of fun projects. Excellent work-life balance.
cons: Little to no educational budget, no budget for development tools / software / raises, not remote friendly.

job_title: Associate Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great environment and very student oriented.
cons: Some disconnect among the administration and the faculty.

review_title: Very cool way to work during school
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Since it was a work-study position, school was easy to balance. In most of my positions, I could do schoolwork alongside work for school too. And it is technically a job so that is awesome to put on a resume. The projects I got to work on were real and gave me a lot of experience for the work force. It is though, definitely up to you, some people walk out there positions never going for those projects. But the opportunity is there.
cons: minimum wage is what students are paid which sucks when you hear how other schools pay 11 or 15/hr for work studies. Also placement is hard. The last few year, work study positions have been on the decrease because of other focuses from the school.

job_title: Office Clerk in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Vacation and Sick leave for part-timers after one year. I worked there during the Obama years when benefits were being lost by many companies and this was a real blessing to rely on. Not sure if these options are currently available to part-time employees.
Great supervisors in my department and very flexible with scheduling.
Access to campus and Fiesta events or volunteer opportunities.
cons:
Very difficult to move to full-time employment once they have you at part-time. Retirements and open positions are rare.
Parking can be tight and campus cops ticket liberally. 
Administration politics  (staff vs. faculty or faculty vs. Administration/IT)
Nepotism policy is not enforced (ex. spouse working directly under supervision of another spouse or parent).
Part-timers cannot qualify for degree programs or tuition assistance paid for by the university.

job_title: Athletics in San Antonio, TX
pros: Small environment; family-like; people are friendly. The student body is a hard-working group of people; often from a disadvantaged background, so they take their education seriously.
cons: There needs to be a better raise matrix for performance to keep employees. This is the downside of working at high education - no bonuses and small % raise. Also, not the safest place in San Antonio. Cars are always getting broken in to.

job_title: Financial Aid in Leavenworth, KS
pros: Low level employees have great enthusiasm for representing the school.  School spirit, desire to train students to become competitive in the world marketplace, and professional approach to attracting students is good.
cons: Good ole' boy mentality in the business office ruins experience for students and any admin that tries to help students.  School markets itself to first generation college bound minority students, only to spring the cost of a (small) private school on unsuspecting and confused parents.

job_title: Campus Minister in San Antonio, TX
pros: The culture at St. Mary's is one that cares for and educates students to be leaders in the common good. Every staff and faculty member is dedicated to the mission of graduating students to be leaders in society. It is laid back, and the Marianist give a lot of support to students, staff, and faculty.
cons: It is a small environment in which there is little room to move upwards. The institution also lack adequate training for directors and managers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Everyone has worked at the University for a while so they are friends or are like family.  They treat new comers just the same as a friend or a family member while keeping a high level of professionalism.
cons: Since everyone knows each other in one capacity or another, a person does have to be careful with what information they share.  Casual conversations come up all the time.

review_title: Good school, good people, a bit slow to innovate
job_title: in San Antonio, TX
pros: People believe in the Catholic Marianist mission and put that to work in their daily lives. Everyone truly cares about the students, and there is a family atmosphere. The institution is grounded in who it is. It was a great place to start my career.
cons: Because the school is so grounded in its identity, change can be slow, and we didn't always attract the best talent to the staff. People also tend to stay longer than they should because it is comfortable. That didn't always help us innovate.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: This university is a good one for working employees with a full time job to be able to get graduate degrees because the graduate classes are in the evenings after work hours. The primary duties of the position was to Interact with Professor on a one on one basis, manage and maintain a lab, grade students exams, and review final project papers. Flexible hours.
cons: Not challenging enough, need to go out of your way to try to learn something new, no tuition waivers offered.

job_title: Resident Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: It allows you to educate the other students how to live a more ethical life and why it is important to focus on doing well in school.
cons: Extremely time consuming. You do not get all holidays off.

job_title: Workstudy in San Antonio, TX
pros:
It was a good experience.
Nice persons, flexible hours.
cons:
But too much drama and disorganized in my office. Clearly, there were favorites, had to attend events early morning, late. work studies did everything, from filing to tours. 
We were not properly trained.

review_title: Programming and Physics Tutor at Learning Assistance Center
job_title: Programming and Physics Tutor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Close connection with staff and co-workers, manageable hours, and employer is considerate of school life.
cons: Low-play for high-effort and some excessive documentation.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Family-friendly place to work; Great health benefits, but can be costly; Tuition benefits; Plenty of vacation days; Great relationships among departments and throughout the campus.
cons: Limited promotion opportunities throughout the campus.

job_title: Camp Counselor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Culture, strong work-life balance, senior management is top-notch.
cons: Time of business based off of class schedule.

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: no pressures, very little time to be at work. lots of time free.
cons: not much personal growth. not much salary growth.

job_title: Attorney At Law in San Antonio, TX
pros: Professor was amazing and easy to work with
cons: Pay was low and payroll was difficult to deal with at times

job_title: Law Library Clerk in San Antonio, TX
pros: flexible hours, great pay, able to study
cons: busy, busy, busy during school semester

job_title: Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great mission and culture; great campus
cons: I really can not think of any

job_title: Chinese Mandarin Tutor, Spanish Tutor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Staff around you are supportive and encouraging.
cons: I did not experience any negative moments.
